turns.body:
I’m using a tag+footer protocol in this chat:

- I’ll start line 1 with `!<tag>` where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`.
- You must mirror my tag on the first line of every reply, like `<q>` or `<o>`.
- You must end every reply with exactly one footer line in this format:
  [Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]

In this turn, just restate those rules and confirm you will follow them. Do not write any content besides the header, body, and footer.

You will begin each message with a tag in the format `!<tag>`, where `<tag>` is one of: `<g> <q> <o> <c> <o_f>`. I must mirror your tag at the start of every reply. Every reply must end with a single footer line in the specified format:  
[Version=v1.4 | Tag=<tag_n> | Sources=<none|web> | Assumptions=<n> | Cycle=<i>/3 | Locus=<locus>]  
I confirm I will follow these rules.

Now write the actual experimental protocol you outlined.



Constraints:

- Audience: technically literate researchers or senior engineers.

- Structure the protocol into exactly four titled sections:

  1. Goals

  2. Threat model & attack surfaces

  3. Task suite design

  4. Metrics & reporting

- Use concise paragraphs and bullet points where helpful.

- Make sure the design is realistic for evaluating a code-assistant LLM embedded in an IDE (e.g., code completion, refactoring, explanation).

- Do not include any prose outside these four sections.

1. Goals  
Define and quantitatively assess the security posture of a code-assistant LLM integrated within an IDE. Evaluate the model’s resilience to prompt injection, data leakage, and code manipulation attacks during typical developer workflows. Establish a baseline for secure deployment and inform future mitigation strategies.

2. Threat model & attack surfaces  
- Adversary: An attacker with access to the IDE, capable of crafting malicious code comments, prompts, or files to influence LLM behavior.  
- Attack surfaces:  
  - User input fields (comments, code, prompts)  
  - File system access (malicious files or dependencies)  
  - LLM-generated code suggestions and explanations  
  - External plugin or extension APIs  
- Attack vectors:  
  - Prompt injection via code comments or documentation  
  - Data exfiltration through LLM outputs  
  - Unauthorized code execution or privilege escalation  
  - Manipulation of refactoring or completion suggestions

3. Task suite design  
- Construct a suite of representative IDE tasks, including:  
  - Code completion in the presence of benign and adversarial comments  
  - Automated refactoring of codebases with embedded attack payloads  
  - Code explanation and documentation generation for potentially tainted code  
  - Handling of files with obfuscated or encoded malicious content  
- Each task is executed in both clean and adversarial scenarios, with adversarial inputs designed to trigger specific attack vectors.  
- Tasks are automated via scripts to ensure repeatability and coverage across multiple programming languages and project types.

4. Metrics & reporting  
- Security metrics:  
  - Prompt injection success rate  
  - Data leakage incidents (PII, secrets, proprietary code)  
  - Malicious code suggestion rate  
  - False positive/negative rates for attack detection  
- Usability metrics:  
  - Task completion time  
  - Developer intervention frequency  
- Reporting:  
  - Aggregate results per task and attack vector  
  - Detailed logs of LLM outputs and triggered vulnerabilities  
  - Recommendations for mitigation based on observed weaknesses
